title: Ayot Greenway Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: HardwareWizard [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Picture of one of the two bridges on Ayot Greenway. This is still in use for farm traffic.

images.title: Robert Edwards / Part of the Ayot Greenway Path, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Part of the Ayot Greenway Path. This public pathway follows part of the disused Luton & Welwyn railway.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / Sherrardspark Wood – Entrance from Campus West Car Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sherrardspark Wood  Entrance from Campus West Car Park. The wood consists of 200 acres of ancient woodland  with oak and hornbeam and much wildlife.

images.title: Peter O'Connor aka anemoneprojectors, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Trail view near Wheathampstead, By 1877, Hertfordshire had eight branch lines; six are now disused and of those, five are now public access routes - Alban Way, Ayot Greenway, Cole Green Way, Ebury Way and the Nickey Line. The Ayot Greenway follows the line that linked Dunstable with Welwyn via Luton, Harpenden, Wheathampstead and Ayot.

images.title: Ayot Greenway, Welwyn Garden City by Christine Johnstone, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: An information board near Welwyn Garden City

images.title: Rob Hinkley / Church, Ayot St Peter, from afar.
images.caption: Church of England parish church, Ayot St Peter: view from the trail, through the trees, This is a nice country view towards the eastern (Welwyn) end of the route.

images.title: Robert Edwards / Part of the High Street in Wheathampstead
images.caption: Part of the High Street in Wheathampstead

description: Follow this disused railway line from Wheathampstead to Welwyn Garden City on this easy cycle or walk in Hertfordshire. It's a nice flat, traffic free path making it ideal for families or beginners looking for an easy cycle ride. Along the way there's good views of the River Lea and a woodland section through Sherrardspark Wood at the end of the route. The woods are also a nature reserve with lots of birdlife and butterflies to look out for. If you're on foot you can extend your walk by picking up the Lea Valley Walk which runs alongside the greenway. If you're on a bike then you could head east to Hertford from Welwyn Garden City along the Cole Green Way. It's another similar rail trail along National Cycle Route 61. This route runs along National Cycle Route 57 which heads west towards Northleach in the Cotswolds.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Just to the east of Sherrardspark Wood you can enjoy refreshments in the Red Lion pub. It's an attractive looking gastropub with beams, wood and stone floors, a large fireplace and Mediterranean-accented food. There's a good varied great menu and a nice courtyard and garden where you can sit outside on warmer days. You can find it at Digswell Hill with a postcode of AL6 9AJ for your sat navs. The Miller & Carter is in a nice position next to the river in Wheathampstead. The pub is housed in an old Tudor building and has a very good menu. There's also a nice outdoor seating area with lovely views. You can find it at 11 High Street with a postcode of AL4 8BS for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: In Sherrardspark Wood there's a public footpath running south to Lemsford where there's nice views of the River Lea and a pretty weir. Near here there's also the Lemsford Springs Nature Reserve where there's good wildlife spotting opportunties. It's only about a 1 mile walk south from the woods so a nice option if you fancy continuing your exercise. Just to the north of the trail you will find the noteworthy village of Ayot St Lawrence. The village is notable for its connections with the playwright George Bernard Shaw and is the site of Shaw's Corner, his old residence. There's also a ruined 12th century church and a lovely pub which dates from the 14th century to see here. It's worth a short detour from the route if you have time. Near here there's Codicote where you can visit the nearby Hoo Park and enjoy some pretty bluebell woods and a rather fine old bridge over the River Mimram. The village is also very attractive with several timber framed buildings and a historic 16th century pub to admire.

display_address: Mount Road, Wheathampstead, St Albans, Hertfordshire, England, AL4 8BU, United Kingdom
